question: Question_04_(ii)
statement:
Consider the function

\[f(x) = \frac{1}{4}x^{4} - 2x^{3} + \frac{9}{2}x^{2}.\]

ii) Find the x-values of all the local maxima and minima of f(x).

\emph{Note: if maxima or minima do not exist, say so.}
sols:
Taking the derivative gives

\[\displaystyle
f'(x) = x^{3} - 6x^{2} + 9x = x(x^{2} - 6x + 9) = x(x-3)^{2}.\]

Which allows to write a sign table for the derivative.

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llllll@{}}
& & $\displaystyle 0$ & & $\displaystyle 3$ &\\
$\displaystyle x$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle 0$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & & $\displaystyle +$\\
Â~$\displaystyle (x-3)^2$ & $\displaystyle +$ & & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle 0$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
Â~$\displaystyle f'(x)$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle 0$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle 0$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
Â~$\displaystyle f(x)$ & $\displaystyle \searrow$ & &
$\displaystyle \nearrow$ & & $\displaystyle \nearrow$\\\\
\end{longtable}

And so we see that the function is decreasing up to \emph{x} = 0, where
it has a global minimum and then is increasing.
